page.text: Proposed Meadows of Lyon Residential Development
This memorandum presents the results of a Traffic Impact Assessment (TIA) for the
proposed Meadows of Lyon residential development in Lyon Township, Michigan. The
project site is located on the south side of 9 Mile Road approximately ¼ mile east of
Griswold Road and is currently undeveloped. The proposed residential development
would include 117 single-family units and would have access to 9 Mile Road via a single
The Township has required a TIA for the project in accordance with Township
Ordinance. The study scope includes the intersection of 9 Mile Road & Griswold Road,
as well as the proposed site access point. The purpose of this study is to identify the
traffic related impacts (if any), of the proposed residential development on the adjacent
Wilcox) collected weekday AM (7:00 AM to 9:00 AM) and PM (4:00 PM to 6:00 PM) peak
period turning movement counts at the intersection of 9 Mile Road with Griswold Road.
In addition to the existing traffic volume data, recent 24-hour volume data was obtained
for the study area from the Southeast Michigan Council of Governments (SEMCOG).
Lastly, F&V collected an inventory of existing lane use and traffic controls. The
applicable data referenced in this memorandum are attached.
The existing AM and PM peak hour traffic volumes were identified based on the data
collected. Existing peak hour vehicle delays and Levels of Service (LOS) were
calculated at the intersection of 9 Mile Road and Griswold Road using Synchro (Version
8) traffic analysis software. This analysis was based on the existing lane use and traffic
control, the existing peak hour traffic volumes, and the methodologies presented in the
Highway Capacity Manual, 2000 (HCM). Typically, LOS D is considered acceptable,
with LOS A representing minimal delay, and LOS F indicating failing conditions.
Additionally, SimTraffic network simulations were reviewed in combination with on-site
observations to evaluate network operations and vehicle queues.
The results of the existing conditions analysis indicate that all critical movements
currently operate at a LOS D or better during both peak hours. Network simulation
indicates that the intersection of 9 Mile Road & Griswold Road operates acceptably and
does not experience significant vehicle queues.
Background conditions, without the proposed development, were evaluated for an
assumed full project buildout of 5 years. Based on historical data obtained from
SEMCOG, a 1% per year growth rate was conservatively applied to the existing traffic
volumes for the analysis of background conditions. Further, a future gravel road paving
project is scheduled for the summer of 2014 on Griswold Road from Eight Mile Road to
Nine Mile Road. Based on current traffic volume data available in the Township Master
Plan, F&V estimates that approximately 50% of existing trips traveling from/to the east at
the intersection of 9 Mile Road & Griswold Road will divert to travel from/to the south due
Additionally, site-generated traffic from two proposed residential developments within the
vicinity of the project site were included in the background conditions analysis. The first
development, known as Woodlands of Lyon, is located on the north side of 9 Mile Road
approximately ½ mile east of Griswold Road and is proposed to include 103 single-
family dwelling units. The second development, known as Estates of Hutsfield, is
located on the northeast corner of 8 Mile Road & Griswold Road and will include 218
single-family dwelling units. Vehicle trips from the Woodlands of Lyon and Estates of
Hutsfield developments were assigned to the study road network based on existing peak
hour traffic patterns and indicate that approximately 90% and 50%, respectively, of site
traffic will travel through the 9 Mile Road & Griswold Road intersection during both peak
The results of the background conditions analysis indicate that vehicle delays and
queues would increase slightly as compared to existing conditions; however, all
intersection approaches and movements would continue to operate acceptably at a LOS
D or better, as shown in Table 2.
The number of AM and PM peak hour vehicle trips that would be generated by the
proposed residential development was forecast based on data published by the Institute
of Transportation Engineers (ITE) in Trip Generation, 9
forecast is summarized in Table 3. The peak hour site trips shown in Table 3 were
assigned to the adjacent road network based on existing traffic patterns. These patterns
indicate that approximately 90% of site traffic would enter/exit the site to/from the west
during the AM and PM peak hours, respectively. The site-generated traffic volumes
to/from the west were distributed through the intersection of 9 Mile Road & Griswold
Road based on existing turning movement percentages.
The site-generated trip assignments were added to the future background traffic
volumes to determine the total future peak hour traffic volumes with the proposed
development. Future peak hour vehicle delays and LOS were calculated at the
intersection of 9 Mile Road & Griswold Road based on these volumes and the existing
intersection lane use and traffic control. The results of the future conditions analysis
indicate that the southbound approach will operate at a LOS F during the PM peak hour,
as shown in Table 4. Additionally, the northbound left turn movement will operate at a
LOS E during the AM peak hour.
Therefore, improvements to mitigate the future operations to be similar to background
conditions were investigated. First, the applicable intersection traffic control warrants
outlined in the 2011 Michigan Manual on Uniform Traffic Control Devices (MMUTCD)
were reviewed for the intersection of 9 Mile Road and Griswold Road. Review of the
traffic signal control warrants indicate that a traffic signal is not warranted at this location.
The intersection traffic volumes are not projected to meet the thresholds of Warrant 1, 2,
or 3. Subsequently, review of the Multi-Way Stop Application guidance was evaluated.
The results of this analysis indicate that future projected traffic volumes at the
intersection meet the minimum volumes criteria utilizing the 70% factor.
With the installation of a 4-Way stop, all intersection movements and approaches would
operate at a LOS D or better during both peak hours, as shown in Table 4. Additionally,
review of network simulations indicates that the intersection operates acceptably and
does not experience significant vehicle queues. An engineering study should be
completed 6 months after the completion of the Griswold paving project to verify that
traffic volumes at the intersection meet the Multi-Way Stop Application criteria.
The Road Commission for Oakland County (RCOC) warrants for right turn deceleration
and left turn passing lanes were evaluated for the proposed intersection of Woodlands
Parkway and 9 Mile Road. The 24-hour volume on 9 Mile Road was determined based
on the SEMCOG 2012 volumes, application of a 1% annual growth rate to project
buildout, and the site-generated traffic forecasts. With the proposed development,
neither left nor right turn lanes are required at the proposed Site Road intersection with 9
The conclusions of this Traffic Impact Assessment are as follows:
1. Currently, all intersection approaches at the intersection of 9 Mile Road &
2. Background traffic volumes at the intersection of 9 Mile Road & Griswold Road
are expected to change due to forecast traffic growth and the paving of Griswold
Road from 8 Mile Road to 9 Mile Road.
3. RCOC should consider installation of Multi-Way stop control at the intersection of
9 Mile Road & Griswold Road if the background traffic volume growth occurs.
4. The proposed Site Access Road with 9 Mile Road will operate acceptably, and
turn lanes on 9 Mile Road are not required.
Any questions related to this memorandum, study, analyses, and results should be
addressed to Fleis & VandenBrink Engineering, Inc.

Peak Hour Analysis From 12:00 PM to 05:45 PM - Peak 1 of 1

The need for a traffic control signal shall be considered if an engineering study finds that one of the following conditions exist for each of any 8 hours of an average day:

text.b: Warrant 1 Conditions A & B met for 0 hours each - WARRANT 1 NOT MET.

page.text: A. The vehicles per hour given in both of the 100 percent columns of Condition A in Table 4C-1 exist on the major-street and the higher-volume minor-street approaches,
B. The vehicles per hour given in both of the 100 percent columns of Condition B in Table 4C-1 exist on the major-street and the higher-volume minor-street approaches,

text.b: Warrant 1 Condition A met for 2 hours - WARRANT 1 NOT MET.

page.text: If the posted or statutory speed limit or the 85th percentile speed on the major street exceeds 40 mph, or if the intersection lies within the built-up area of an isolated community having a
population of less than 10,000, the traffic volumes in the 70 percent columns in Table 4C-1 may be used in place of the 100 percent columns.

text.b: Warrant 2 conditions met for 0 hours - WARRANT 2 NOT MET.

page.text: The need for a traffic control signal shall be considered if an engineering study finds that, for each of any 4 hours of an
average day, the plotted points representing the vehicles per hour on the major street (total of both approaches) and the
corresponding vehicles per hour on the higher-volume minor-street approach (one direction only) all fall above the
applicable curve in Figure 4C-1 for the existing combination of approach lanes. On the minor street, the higher volume
shall not be required to be on the same approach during each of these 4 hours.
* Curve Threshold represents the minor street (higher volume) approach corresponding to the observed major street
volume (both approaches) and the curve for 2 or more lanes & 2 or more lanes.

text.b: Warrant 2 conditions met for 1 hours - WARRANT 2 NOT MET.

page.text: If the posted or statutory speed limit or the 85th percentile speed on the major street exceeds 40 mph, or if the
intersection lies within the built-up area of an isolated community having a population of less than 10,000, Figure 4C-2
may be used in place of Figure 4C-1. .
* Curve Threshold represents the minor street (higher volume) approach corresponding to the observed major street
volume (both approaches) and the curve for 2 or more lanes & 2 or more lanes.
The need for a traffic control signal shall be considered if an engineering study finds that the criteria in either of
the following two categories are met:
This signal warrant shall be applied only in unusual cases, such as office complexes, manufacturing plans, industrial
complexes, or high-occupancy vehicle facilities that attract or discharge large numbers of vehicles over a short time.

page.text: A. If all three of the following conditions exist for the same 1 hour (any four consecutive 15-minute periods) of
1. The total stopped time delay experienced by the traffic on one minor-street approach (one direction
only) controlled by a STOP sign equals or exceeds: 4 vehicle-hours for a one-lane approach; or 5 vehicle-
hours for a two-lane approach, and
2. The volume on the same minor street approach (one direction only) equals or exceeds 100 vehicles
per hour for one moving lane of traffic or 150 vehicles per hour for two moving lanes, and
